did.head: Collection Summary

physdesc.label: Extent
physdesc.extent: 15 manuscript boxes, 3 portfolios, 7 boxes of bound manuscripts, 1 box of checks, 1 box of printed short stories

did.abstract: The Foote Collection contains correspondence, miscellaneous written and printed material, photographs, and works of art produced by multiple generations of the families of Eli Foote (1747-1792) and Samuel Edmund Foote (1787-1858) and their friends and associates. The Foote Family is important in the history of Connecticut because its members were among the founders of Wethersfield, New Haven and Guilford. The family is connected by marriage to the Beechers.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open and available for research.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Harriet Beecher Stowe Center.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], , [Box no]., Harriet Beecher Stowe Center

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Material in the Foote Collection was obtained from various sources as listed below.
1. Various material was donated in 1977, 1980, and 1981 by Margaret Foote Oppenheimer, Mrs. William J. Foote, and Ambassador John D. Moore.
2. Letters of Samuel E. Foote, the Godkin family, Calvin Stowe, and Alfred Rockwell were purchased from Maurice Sagoff in 1978.
3. Letters of Joseph R. Hawley, James D. Hague, and Kate Foote Rockwell were obtained from Maurice Sagoff in 1978.
4. 24 letters by Joseph R. Hawley and books, were donated by Edward J. Foote In 1978.
5. Foote family photographs and postcards were donated by Christopher S. Foote and Mary Foote Rounsavall in 1986.

6. Photographs, magazine articles, newspaper clippings, exhibit catalogs, invitations, correspondence, and documents by and about Margaret Foote Hawley and her art work were donated by Christopher S. Foote and Mary Foote Rounsavall in 1986.

6. Margaret Foote Hawley panel paintings, library materials, photos, other items and her letters regarding paintings and art shows, were donated by Christopher S. Foote and Mary Foote Rounsavall in 1987.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: The Foote Family is descended from Nathaniel Foote, who emigrated from Colchester, England first to the Massachusetts Bay Colony and then, along with Andrew Ward and eight other 'adventurers,' in 1634, to the new settlement of Wethersfield, Connecticut. In the next century, Eli Foote (1747-1792) married Roxana Ward (1751-1840) and had eight children, five of whom grew to adulthood. Their second daughter, Roxana Foote (1775-1816) married the young minister, Lyman Beecher (1775-1863) and was the mother of nine of his 13 children including Catharine Beecher (1800-1878), Harriet Beecher Stowe (1811-1896), and Henry Ward Beecher (1813-1887).

Most of the documents in the Foote Collection relate to the children and grandchildren of Eli and Roxana Foote and their spouses. Major contributors include John Parsons Foote, Samuel Edmund Foote, George Augustus Foote, Katharine Foote Coe, Harriet Foote Hawley, Christopher Spencer Foote, Arthur DeWint Foote, Katharine Foote Rockwell, and Andrew Ward Foote. Another major contributor is Edward Hopkins Jenkins, husband of granddaughter Elizabeth Foote.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Foote Collection is an eclectic assortment that includes correspondence, accounts, printed material, transcripts, bound manuscripts, photographs, drawings, and paintings reflecting the tastes, talents, interests, and activities of many family members and several generations.

Most of the documents in the Foote Collection relate to the children of Eli and Roxana Foote, notably John Parsons (1783-1865), Samuel Edmund (1787-1858), and George Augustus (1789-1878), and grandchildren including author and educator Katharine Foote Coe (1840-1923) and Harriet Foote Hawley (1831-1886), a Civil War nurse and wife of Connecticut governor and U.S. Senator, Joseph Roswell Hawley (1826-1905). Samuel Edmund Foote is Captain Sam Foote, the famous romantic uncle of Harriet Beecher Stowe, whose biography by his brother, John Parsons Foote, is also held by the Stowe Center.

Other notable relatives by marriage include Edwin L. Godkin, (1831-1902) founder and editor of The Nation magazine, and author and artist, Mary Hallock Foote (1847-1938). Other grandchildren who are major contributors to the collection are Christopher Spencer Foote (1837-1880), Arthur DeWint Foote (1849-1933), Katharine Foote Rockwell (1839-1902), and Edward Hopkins Jenkins (1850-1931), husband of Elizabeth Foote Jenkins (1852-1936).
The Foote Collection also contains materials from the family of another grandson, Andrew Ward Foote, one of George Augustus Foote's 10 children.

The collection includes correspondence from authors Jacob Riis, Samuel L. Clemens, Frances Hodgson Burnett, George Washington Cable, and John C. Schwab; as well as poet May Sarton. There are also materials from William Tecumseh Sherman; George Washington; Alexander Hamilton; Connecticut governors Oliver Wolcott, Samuel Huntington, and Jonathan Trumbull; and actor William Gillette. The collection does not contain materials on the Harriet Ward Foote Taylor/Addison Taylor line of Princeton, New Jersey and Scarsdale, New York.

The collection's geography covers most of the eastern United States as well as Alaska, California, Idaho, Minnesota, Ohio. International locations include Canada, England, Germany, Italy, Jamaica, Portugal, Mexico, Spain, Trinidad, Barbados, Liberia, and Cuba.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Foote Collection is arranged alphabetically by author, then chronologically.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Collections
relatedmaterial.p: Additional Foote Family correspondence can be found in the Acquisitions, Katharine S. Day, Gillette, Isabella Beecher Hooker, and White Collections.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Foote family photographs are stored within the Photograph Collection, and artwork catalogued in the Object Collection.
